body:
Great explanation. 
Thank you very much for the excellent support.

I wasn't aware that the batch is only initialized once to 0 and then just overwritten in the desired positions.

Thanks again.
@Godricly @CNevd  Thanks for your advice.
I tested on latest build, it seems okay now.

Is your mxnet version latest? There was memcpy error( #6121 ) because of contrib.warpctc once but as far as I know, it is okay now.   
So 1. you can remove your version of mxnet and clone recursive/compile latest build of mxnet.  
2. If you don't want to clone latest mxnet again, I recommend to re-compile but remove the folder ctc_include, and files ctc_loss.cc, ctc_loss.cu and ctc_loss-inl.h from ~/mxnet/src/operator/contrib.
(But I'm not sure your error would be solved by number 2.)

@yajiedesign 
is it possible or how to feed the network with variable size image ?

I create a small network but I have a problem regarding binding. I also want to use the sgd optimizer but I don't know where to put it. I read some topic but I do not really understand what I have to do.

```

def get_shared_network(data, fc1_weight, fc1_bias, fc2_weight, fc2_bias):
    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, name='fc1', num_hidden=128, weight=fc1_weight, bias=fc1_bias)
    act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc1, name='relu1', act_type="relu")
    fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=act1, name='fc2', num_hidden=64, weight=fc2_weight, bias=fc2_bias)
    act2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc2, name='relu2', act_type="relu")

    return act2

def get_two_network():
    data1 = mx.sym.Variable('data1')
    data2 = mx.symbol.Variable('data2')

    fc1_w = mx.sym.Variable('fc1_w', init=mx.init.Constant(0.02))
    fc2_w = mx.symbol.Variable('fc2_w', init=mx.init.Constant(0.01))
    fc1_b = mx.sym.Variable('fc1_b', init=mx.init.Constant(0.08))
    fc2_b = mx.symbol.Variable('fc2_b', init=mx.init.Constant(0.09))

    act2_1 = get_shared_network(data1, fc1_w, fc1_b, fc2_w, fc2_b)
    act2_2 = get_shared_network(data2, fc1_w, fc1_b, fc2_w, fc2_b)
    fc3_1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=act2_1, name='fc3_1', num_hidden=5)
    fc3_2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=act2_2, name='fc3_2', num_hidden=5)
    softmax1 = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3_1, name='softmax1')
    softmax2 = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3_2, name='softmax2')
    return [softmax1, softmax2]

# Data
imgrec_train1 = 'mnistasjpg/train_data1' + '.rec'
imglist_train1 = 'mnistasjpg/train_data1' + '.lst'

imgrec_test1 = 'mnistasjpg/test_data1' + '.rec'
imglist_test1 = 'mnistasjpg/test_data1' + '.lst'

imgrec_train2 = 'mnistasjpg/train_data2' + '.rec'
imglist_train2 = 'mnistasjpg/train_data2' + '.lst'

imgrec_test2 = 'mnistasjpg/test_data2' + '.rec'
imglist_test2 = 'mnistasjpg/test_data2' + '.lst'

# # load dataset
train_dataiter1 = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec=imgrec_train1,
        data_shape=(3, x, y),
        batch_size=batch_size,
        path_imglist=imglist_train1,
        preprocess_threads=1,
        label_width=1,
        data_name='data1',
        label_name='softmax1_label',
        # shuffle=True,
        # shuffle_chunk_seed=100,
        # seed=100,
        # rand_mirror=True,
        # rand_mirror_prob=0.5,
        # random_crop=True
)
print('testing Dataset ...')
# Data validation
test_dataiter1 = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec=imgrec_test1,
    data_shape=(3, x, y),
    batch_size=batch_size,
    path_imglist=imglist_test1,
    preprocess_threads=1,
    label_width=1,
    data_name='data1',
    label_name='softmax1_label'
)

train_dataiter2 = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec=imgrec_train2,
        data_shape=(3, x, y),
        batch_size=batch_size,
        path_imglist=imglist_train2,
        preprocess_threads=1,
        label_width=1,
        data_name='data2',
        label_name='softmax2_label',
        #shuffle=True,
        # shuffle_chunk_seed=100,
        # seed=100,
        #rand_mirror=True,
        #rand_mirror_prob=0.5,
        #random_crop=True
)
print('testing Dataset ...')
# Data validation
test_dataiter2 = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec=imgrec_test2,
    data_shape=(3, x, y),
    batch_size=batch_size,
    path_imglist=imglist_test2,
    preprocess_threads=1,
    label_width=1,
    data_name='data2',
    label_name='softmax2_label'
)

sgd = mx.optimizer.create('sgd', learning_rate=.001, momentum=0.9, wd=0.0005)
name_model = get_two_network()

# load network 
mod1 = mx.mod.Module(name_model[0], context=mx.cpu(), data_names=['data1'], label_names=[output_name])
mod1.bind(data_shapes=[('data1', (1, 3, x, y))], label_shapes=[(output_name, (1,))] )
mod1.init_params()
mod2 = mx.mod.Module(name_model[1], context=mx.cpu(), data_names=['data2'], label_names=[output_name2])
mod2.bind(data_shapes=[('data2', (1, 3, x, y))], label_shapes=[(output_name2, (1,))] )
mod2.init_params()

# train

batch = train_dataiter1.next()
mod1.forward(batch, is_train= True)
result = mod1.get_outputs()[0]
print(result.asnumpy())
#mod1.backward(sgd)
mod1.update()
```


The error :
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mxnet_shared.py", line 164, in <module>
    mod1.update()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/mxnet-0.10.1-py3.5.egg/mxnet/module/module.py", line 610, in update
    assert self.binded and self.params_initialized and self.optimizer_initialized
AssertionError
```

EDIT : I maybe solve the problem adding this : 
`mod1.init_optimizer(kvstore='local', optimizer='sgd', optimizer_params=(('learning_rate', 0.001),('momentum', 0.9),('wd', 0.0005) ))`
There is similar blas library called flame/blis and lapack. These are more complete than weblas. If any one try to migrate mxnet, these are worth to try.

@piiswrong hmm, that's usually very difficult to track down in case of any dispute. so generally should be discouraged, unless the contribution/commit/PR is made by the original owner of the code.

assuming we already code snippets taken from other projects in the source already, likely the best way is to attribute them as in:

> for source included, reference the relative file path of each file and list them in the LICENSE file eg. https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/LICENSE

might be good to consult legal-discuss @ ASF on that too.

This issue is resolved. Closing.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/7000 Same as this issue. Can be closed.

1. When running in dist_sync mode training would come to a halt if one of the workers or servers is down. So that is a hint. But your observation may still be valid. What information do you think would be useful for diagnostic purposes.


2. This probably does not answer your question, but I'm curious to know why you want to do this? Are you running in a shared environment? You probably don't want to run in sync mode here otherwise your gpu workers will sit idle most of the time waiting for cpu workers. Even in async mode, there is a marked asymmetry between the rates at which gpus and cpus can process input data.

@piiswrong It seems that one step of the pipeline blew up due to a timeout. Is there a way you guys can restart this step manually?

It seems I cannot train with batch size more than 1 on each GPU, will there be a fix for this. (I guess this will be a feature request)

@madjam Thanks for your comments!
1. Considering data parallelism, as each worker works on one partition of the data, if we can monitor
    1) the overall data processed by all the workers (represented by the total number of processed batches for example) 
   2) the progress each worker has made (represented by the local processed batches) since the work launched.
   Then it will be very helper for us to have a global view of the ongoing distributed learning process.
2. To be frank, I am new to deep learning, so the following concerns are mostly hypothetical. 
One of the scenario I can come up with is what if there are not enough computation resource for you to do the computation. Although intuitively, the more GPUs we have the quicker the learning process, but we always have a limited number of GPU. Under this circumstances, if we can leverage the computation capacity of the idle CPU cluster in our system, we will get extra performance gain. 
Another concern would be is that possible some of the computation is processed faster on CPU? I know that computation like matrix multiplication will be extremely fast if we use GPU. But I am not sure that is always the case for all kinds of computation in deep learning algorithms.
Do these two concerns make sense to you?

================MY SUGGESTION for warpctc plugin=============
when I used mxnet , I learned a lot of ,lot of ,not just how to use it ,but also the design skill, optimized skill behind mxnet.  it has been my most favorite DL framework, the most!
but to each new MXNETer like me , the small failed sometimes really frustrated, one of them is the so many issue is waiting for reply, some of them maybe no reply at all, so sometiems work is suspended. So the readme of each project based on mxnet should be detailed.

**to warpctc plugin ,my suggestion is** 

1:config.mk  related info is from

 WARPCTC_PATH = $(HOME)/warp-ctc
 MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/warpctc/warpctc.mk

to

 You also need to add warp-ctc/build/ to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH
 WARPCTC_PATH = $(HOME)/warp-ctc
 MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/warpctc/warpctc.mk

2: if the comparitibility between warpctc and contributer's version is not fixed,  I suggest directly delete the choice 2 files  from the repository until fixed by namespace isolate or other method.

well, finally ,hope somedays ,I could become one of the contributers to contribute something :)

Glad to hear problem solved, I agree with MXNet is great platform, and nowadays many contributors contributes to build awesome documents including installation, and especially Warp CTC is now get into the builtin plugin as contrib.warpctc, I expect small failures will goes away.

using `python -m pdb you_train_command` to invoke python debug mode, then you can set breakpoints and run step by step, check value of variables, which may be useful to find where is the bug

**some tips**
while writing you own operator, don't use `asnumpy` before you try all other possible way, it's time expensive

Oops, my bad. Could you try compare two objects with Python operator `is` ?

BTW, did you just use two different `mod`? I suppose theses models are different, although they have same name for the weight.

find the random method is come from `import random` or `np.random`, and call correspond seed function, or you can use below for both(at the begin of code)
```python
import random
import numpy as np

if '__main__'==__name:
    random.seed(0)
    np.random.seed(0)

    # other codes
```

if the result is not what you want, find call code that call random.*, comment what's commentable

if you are using *unix, this command may be useful
```shell
grep -R . -e 'random' --exclude-dir data $(find . -name '*.py')
```

some other tips:
1. change DataIter's next function, make it alway generate same samples every time
1. change the batch_size to 1 if neccessary

@nnguyen24 You need to make the two symbols in `mx.symbol.Correlation` have exactly the same shape:

```r
library(mxnet)

train.x = matrix(data = rexp(120 * 319, rate = 10), nrow = 120, ncol = 319)

# Define the input data
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
# Define the first fully connected layer
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden = 100)
act.fun <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc1, act_type = "relu") # create a hidden layer with Rectified Linear Unit as its activation function.
output <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act.fun, num_hidden = 319)
# Customize loss function
label <- mx.symbol.Variable("label")
lro <- mx.symbol.MakeLoss(mx.symbol.Correlation(
  mx.symbol.reshape(output, shape = c(100, 319, 1, 1)),
  mx.symbol.reshape(label, shape = c(100, 319, 1, 1))))

model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(symbol = lro, X = t(train.x),
                                     y = t(train.x), num.round = 5,
                                     array.batch.size = 100,
                                     optimizer = "sgd",
                                     learning.rate = 0.0003,
                                     array.layout = "colmajor",
                                     epoch.end.callback = mx.callback.log.train.metric(20, logger))
```

```
git clone https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet.git
```

1. [Module.fit](http://mxnet.io/api/python/module.html#mxnet.module.BaseModule.fit) lets your supply callbacks that will be invoked when events of interest such as batch end, epoch end occur. You can supply a logging call back to have it print out stats.
2. Operations that consume lots of FLOPS are better run on GPUs, assuming you have them available. In some cases the discrepancy in training times (between CPU and GPU) is so big that you probably are better off waiting for a GPU to become available. You could conceivably use a cluster of CPUs if you are not training the entire network i.e. taking a pre-trained model and fine tuning it with new labeled data. I do think your questions/concerns are valid. It is just that CPUs and GPUs are optimized for different types of workloads.
Thank you. I am not familiar with python.  Is the the directory src/c_api only for python interface? Is it use CTypes or CPython?
It's not only for python. Other language can use those c apis too. By default it uses ctypes, but you can switch to cython as well.

closing this PR. opened new one https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/7038

Thanks for bringing this up. @piiswrong shall we do the following?
```
def _check_lengths_equal(labels, preds):
    label_len = len(labels) if hasattr(labels, '__len__') else labels.shape[0]
    pred_len = len(preds) if hasattr(preds, '__len__') else preds.shape[0]

    if label_len != pred_len:
        raise ValueError("Length of labels {} does not match length of "
                         "predictions {}".format(label_len, pred_len))
```
Or we can add __len__ to ndarray to return the size of the first dimension, as was done by numpy.

Symbol does not have data inside, but module's get_params() does have information you want.
as http://mxnet.io/api/python/module.html#mxnet.module.BaseModule.get_params
have tensor values you want.
```
print mod.get_params()
args_params, aux_params = mod.get_params()
args_params['key_you_want_to_see'].asnumpy()
```
Yeah I could. Check if the CLASSES are set correctly at training and in demo.py. If you train with a single class, you need to set CLASS =[classname,] otherwise len(CLASS) returns a wrong value.

About **1. Using print(mxnet.ndarray) in all section**, I've resolved this by building MXNet from source.

Another thing, are instructions listed in http://mxnet.io/get_started/windows_setup.html still valid? I found out that many steps are no longer valid. E.g.
1. Visual Studio 2013 is no longer available in the Microsoft Visual Studio website.
2. There is no troubleshooting guide for failure encountered as well. Mostly related to cmake error as well as OS-specific issue, such as Windows 10.

Hi @codentropy,

I've encountered the same error with yours. Here's one of the ways I've got it to work:
1. Open .\mxnet\build\CMakeCache.txt file.
2. Replace 
`MKL_RT_LIBRARY:FILEPATH=MKL_RT_LIBRARY-NOTFOUND`
with the following line:
`MKL_RT_LIBRARY:FILEPATH=C:\Program Files (x86)\IntelSWTools\compilers_and_libraries_2017.4.210\windows\mkl\lib\ia32_win`
